Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Bridging Geometric Manifold Theory and Higher-Dimensional Data Modeling for Visual Computing

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration: The long-term goal of this research aims to systematically trailblaze a novel geometric manifold theory founded upon continuous polynomial representations, and to apply this mathematically-rigorous theory to both shape geometry and higher-dimensional, multi-attribute data modeling, analysis and visualization, with a special emphasis on visual computing applications. The research team is exploring new geometric manifold theory at the interface of differential geometry, numerical approximation theory, computational topology, and linear algebra. The study of new and important geometric manifold theory enables the accurate and effective modeling of higher-dimensional, multi-attribute volumetric datasets which are of complicated geometry, arbitrary topology, and with rich geometric features. This theory-centered research provides a sound theoretical foundation for rapid data modeling and data analysis. It has a potential to streamline the entire virtual prototyping processes for digital engineering in the future with longer-term research efforts by expediting data transformation from discrete samples to continuous manifold and spline-centric visual data representations.

Project Title: Bridging Geometric Manifold Theory and Higher-Dimensional Data Modeling for Visual ComputingIntellectual Merits: Real-world, higher-dimensional,multi-attribute datasets are oftentimes of arbitrarily complicated topology with local/global manifold structure. In order to bridge the large gap between conventional geometric theory and the strong demand to accurately and efficiently model acquired datasets towards quantitative analysis and effective data management and visualization, our research effort will concentrate on the under-explored geometric theory of manifold spline functions, differential manifolds in 3D and higher dimension, and piecewise-polynomial-centric spline formulations, that will afford continuous representations to effectively model higher-dimensional, multi-attribute visual data of arbitrary topology. Because of the small-scale nature of this exploratory, and high-risk/high-payoff initiative, we conduct the comprehensive study of new and important geometric manifold theory that can enable the accurate and effective modeling of higher-dimensional, multi-attribute volumetric datasets which are of complicated geometry, arbitrary topology, and with rich geometric features.
Project PI: Hong Qin, SUNY at Stony Brook (Stony Brook University)
The long-term goal of this research aims to systematically trailblaze a novel geometric manifold theory founded upon continuous polynomial representations, and to apply this mathematically-rigorous theory to both shape geometry and higher-dimensional, multi-attribute data modeling, analysis and visualization, with a special emphasis on visual computing applications. In order to achieve this ambitious, longer-term objective, the concrete and specific goal is to explore new geometric manifold theory at the interface of differential geometry, numerical approximation theory, computational topology, and linear algebra. At present, continuous representations such as spline functions are becoming ubiquitous, with widespread and deep penetration into many scientific and engineering fields including functional data analysis, reverse engineering, medical image processing, numerical solutions of partial differential equations, data representation and visualization, data matching and registration from abstract space to geometric space, data parameterization over geometric domain, etc. This project is a small-scale, exploratory, and high-risk/high-payoff initiative on novel geometric manifold theory for higher-dimensional,multi-attribute data of arbitrary topology, which has not yet been seriously explored.
